revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2019}} {{short description|Astronomical objects catalogued by Charles Messier}} {{Infobox astronomical survey | type = astronomical catalogue }} The '''Messier objects''' are a set of 110 [[astronomical objects]] catalogued by the French astronomer [[Charles Messier]] in his ''Catalogue des Nébuleuses et des Amas d'Étoiles'' ("Catalogue of Nebulae and Star Clusters"). Because Messier was only interested in finding [[comet]]s, he created a list of non-comet objects that frustrated his hunt for them. The compilation of this list, in collaboration with his assistant [[Pierre Méchain]], is known as ''the Messier catalogue.'' This catalogue of objects is one of the most famous lists of astronomical objects, and many Messier objects are still referenced by their Messier number. {{cite web | title= Original Messier Catalog of 1781 | url= http://messier.seds.org/xtra/Mcat/mcat1781.html#messier1781 | date= 10 November 2007 }} The catalogue includes some astronomical objects that can be observed from Earth's [[Northern Hemisphere]] such as [[deep-sky object]]s, a characteristic which makes the Messier objects extremely popular targets for amateur astronomers.{{Cite web |url=https://www.nasa.gov/content/goddard/hubble-s-messier-catalog |title=NASA |last=Garner |first=Rob |date=18 December 2018 |publisher=[[NASA]] |url-status=live |access-date=17 January 2019}} A preliminary version first appeared in the ''Memoirs'' of the [[French Academy of Sciences]] in 1771. {{cite web | title= Charles Messier's Original Catalog of 1771 | date= 15 June 2007 | work= Students for the Exploration and Development of Space | url= https://web.archive.org/web/20170313190707/http://messier.seds.org/xtra/history/m-cat71.html | accessdate= 5 November 2015 }} {{cite web | title= Messier catalog | website= Encyclopædia Britannica | url= http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/377197/Messier-catalog | accessdate= 27 May 2015 }} The first version of Messier's catalogue contained 45 objects and was published in 1774 in the journal of the French Academy of Sciences in Paris. Eighteen of the objects were discovered by Messier, the rest being previously observed by other astronomers.{{cite magazine |last=Gingerich |first=Owen |date=September 1953 |title=Messier and His Catalogue II |url= https://archive.org/details/Sky_and_Telescope_1953-09-cbr |magazine=Sky & Telescope |issue=142}} By 1780 the catalogue had increased to 80 objects. The final version of the catalogue containing 103 objects was published in 1781 in the ''[[Connaissance des Temps]]'' for the year 1784.Charles Messier, 1781. Catalogue des Nébuleuses & des amas d'Étoiles. Connoissance des Temps pour l'Année 1784 (published 1781), pp. 227–267 {{Bibcode|1781CdT..1784..227M}}.
{{cite web | title= Original Messier Catalog of 1781 | url= http://messier.seds.org/xtra/Mcat/mcat1781.html#messier1781 | accessdate= 10 November 2007 }} However, due to what was thought for a long time to be the incorrect addition of [[Messier 102]], the total number remained 102. Other astronomers, using side notes in Messier's texts, eventually filled out the list up to 110 objects. {{cite web | title= SEDS Messier Database | work= The Messier Catalog | date= 27 May 2015 | url= http://messier.seds.org/ }} The catalogue consists of a diverse range of astronomical objects, from [[star clusters]] and [[nebulae]] to [[galaxies]]. For example, Messier 1 is a [[supernova remnant]], known as the [[Crab Nebula]], and the great [[spiral galaxy|spiral]] [[Andromeda Galaxy]] is M31. Many further inclusions followed in the next century when the first addition came from [[Nicolas Camille Flammarion]] in 1921, who added [[Messier 104]] after finding Messier's side note in his 1781 edition exemplar of the catalogue. [[Messier 105|M105]] to [[Messier 107|M107]] were added by [[Helen Sawyer Hogg]] in 1947, [[Messier 108|M108]] and [[Messier 109|M109]] by [[Owen Gingerich]] in 1960, and [[Messier 110|M110]] by Kenneth Glyn Jones in 1967. {{cite book | first= Patrick | last= Moore | date= 1979 | title= The Guinness Book of Astronomy | publisher= [[Guinness Superlatives]] | isbn= 978-0-900424-76-2 | url-access= registration | url= https://archive.org/details/guinnessbookofas00moor }} ==Lists and editions== [[File:Charles Messier.jpg|275px|thumb|[[Charles Messier]]|alt=Painting of Charles Messier]] The first edition of 1771 covered 45 objects numbered [[Crab Nebula|M1]] to [[Pleiades|M45]]. The total list published by Messier in 1781 contained 103 objects, but the list was expanded through successive additions by other astronomers, motivated by notes in Messier's and Méchain's texts indicating that at least one of them knew of the additional objects. The first such addition came from [[Nicolas Camille Flammarion]] in 1921, who added [[Messier 104]] after finding a note Messier made in a copy of the 1781 edition of the catalogue. [[Messier 105|M105]] to [[Messier 107|M107]] were added by [[Helen Sawyer Hogg]] in 1947, [[Messier 108|M108]] and [[Messier 109|M109]] by [[Owen Gingerich]] in 1960, and [[Messier 110|M110]] by Kenneth Glyn Jones in 1967. {{cite book |author=Patrick Moore |date=1979 |title=The Guinness Book of Astronomy |publisher=[[Guinness Superlatives]] |isbn=0-900424-76-1 |url-access=registration |url=https://archive.org/details/guinnessbookofas00moor }} [[Messier 102|M102]] was observed by Méchain, who communicated his notes to Messier. Méchain later concluded that this object was simply a re-observation of M101, though some sources suggest that the object Méchain observed was the galaxy [[NGC 5866]] and identify that as M102.{{Cite web |url=http://www.messier.seds.org/xtra/supp/m102art.txt |title= Messier 102 |last=Frommert |first=Hartmut |date=10 May 1995 |publisher=MSFC X-Ray Astronomy's InterNetNews site |url-status=live |access-date=24 February 2019}} Messier's final catalogue was included in the ''[[Connaissance des Temps]] pour l'Année 1784'' (''Knowledge of Time''; published in 1781), the French official yearly publication of astronomical [[ephemerides]]. {{cite book |author=Charles Messier |date=1781 |chapter=Catalogue des Nébuleuses & des amas d'Étoiles |title=Connaissance des Temps pour l'Année 1784 |pages=227–267 }} {{cite web | title=Original Messier Catalog of 1781 | work=Original Messier Catalog of 1781 | url=http://messier.seds.org/xtra/Mcat/mcat1781.html | publisher=[[Students for the Exploration and Development of Space|SEDS]] | accessdate=17 May 2014 }} Messier lived and did his astronomical work at the Hôtel de Cluny (now the [[Musée national du Moyen Âge]]), in [[Paris]], France. The list he compiled contains only objects found in the sky area he could observe: from the north [[celestial pole]] to a celestial latitude of about −35.7°. He did not observe or list objects visible only from farther south, such as the [[Large Magellanic Cloud|Large]] and [[Small Magellanic Cloud|Small]] [[Magellanic Clouds]].{{cite book |last1=English |first1=Neil |title=Chronicling the golden age of astronomy : a history of visual observing from Harriot to Moore |date=2018 |publisher=Springer |isbn=3319977075 |page=91 |url=https://books.google.se/books?id=b9p1DwAAQBAJ&pg=PA91&lpg=PA91&source=bl&ots=jf8JWJ7Moa&sig=ACfU3U0albF2cMdSvroUUIzkND47wAwP_Q&hl=en&sa=X&ved=2ahUKEwipp9GyhZDlAhVKAxAIHTlkA4wQ6AEwDXoECAkQAQ#v=onepage&q&f=false |accessdate=9 October 2019}} ==Observations== The Messier catalogue comprises nearly all the most spectacular examples of the five types of [[deep-sky object]] – [[diffuse nebulae]], [[planetary nebula]]e, [[open cluster]]s, [[globular cluster]]s, and [[galaxy|galaxies]] – visible from European latitudes. Furthermore, almost all of the Messier objects are among the closest to Earth in their respective classes, which makes them heavily studied with professional class instruments that today can resolve very small and visually spectacular details in them. A summary of the astrophysics of each Messier object can be found in the ''Concise Catalog of Deep-sky Objects.'' {{cite book |author=W.H. Finlay |date=2003 |title=Concise Catalog of Deep-sky Objects: Astrophysical Information for 500 Galaxies |publisher=[[Springer (publisher)|Springer]] |isbn=1-85233-691-9 }} Since these objects could be observed visually with the relatively small-aperture [[refracting telescope]] (approximately 100 mm, or 4 inches) used by Messier to study the sky, they are among the brightest and thus most attractive [[astronomical object]]s (popularly called [[deep-sky object]]s) observable from Earth, and are popular targets for visual study and [[astrophotography]] available to modern [[amateur astronomy|amateur astronomers]] using larger aperture equipment. In early spring, astronomers sometimes gather for "[[Messier marathon]]s", when all of the objects can be viewed over a single night. {{cite web |date=19 March 2013 |title=The Messier Marathon |url=http://messier.seds.org/xtra/marathon/marathon.html |publisher=[[Students for the Exploration and Development of Space|SEDS]] |accessdate=17 May 2014 }}{{cite book |last1=Stoyan |first1=Ronald |last2=Binnewies |first2=Stefan |last3=Friedrich |first3=Susanne |title=Atlas of the Messier Objects: Highlights of the Deep Sky |date=2008 |publisher=Cambridge University Press |isbn=9783319977072}} == Messier objects == {{legend4|#eeeeff|[[Open cluster]]|border=1px solid #aaaaaa}} {{legend4|#ffe4b5|[[Globular cluster]]|border=1px solid #aaaaaa}} {{legend4|#ffcccc|[[Diffuse nebula]]|border=1px solid #aaaaaa}} {{legend4|#ccffee|[[Planetary nebula]]|border=1px solid #aaaaaa}} {{legend4|#ffccee|[[Supernova remnant]]|border=1px solid #aaaaaa}} {{legend4|#ffffcc|[[Galaxy]]|border=1px solid #aaaaaa}} {{legend4|#ffffff|Other|border=1px solid #aaaaaa}} {{Clear}} {| class="wikitable sortable" |- !
